reviewText: If you are over 30 years old (like me) you most likely played this back on a 286/386/486.. (well, the other Keen games at least). Keen is iconic! Keen was the game I first downloaded off the internet, in 1994-95 it took 1 hour to download the 2 or 3MB shareware episode on 33.6kbps dialup at a net cafe. Waste of money essentially but it was 'exciting' to wait 1 hour to download something that otherwise would have had to buy on a shareware disk. Epic platformers, similar to Super Mario 3 with the world map screen (more choices though as it is an open map, unlike the SMB3 map which has rails to move on) but with no 'killing' of enemies. The foodstuffs you fight, you have to throw things at them, they turn to flowers and then respawn a few moments later. If you never played this (or even if did and want a journey down memory lane) - get it! It might look 'crap' to you but imagine your other option in the very early 90s for PC gaming - it was way up there! Similar to: Captain Comic

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_i-CZENpIuU

If you are unaware, Keen Dreams is the black sheep/prodigal son/forgotten chapter of the Commander Keen series. It falls somewhere between the end of Invasion of the Vorticons and Goodbye Galaxy, so that effectively makes it episode 3.5 or some such nonsense. Since then it’s floated around like a chunk of loose cat hair, with an Android release in 2013 by Super Fighter Team and now this crowd-funded re-release for the PC by Javier Chavez. This includes not only the source code, but an updated port of the game for Windows, Linux, and Mac OS computers. Pretty snazzy in concept -- and in reality!

This isn’t a complete overhaul or anything, this is just a port with a few extra thingies. Thingies like modern gamepad support, widescreen and windowed mode graphics options, cloud saving, achievements, and even a switch for CGA and EGA mode right from the main menu.

As for the game itself, well, it’s the same pared-down Keen experience as it was before. The story is that Keen refused to eat his veggies one night, then has nightmares about it where vegetables are torturing him in the land of Tuberia. Dressed in pajamas and armed only with hippy-fied flower power seeds, it’s your goal to collect enough boobus bombs to eventually defeat the giant sentient potato, King Boobus Tuber. Most notably, you don’t have a pogo stick, which puts it up for debate as to whether or not this is even a Keen game at all without his trademark power-up. Some other things are missing as they were in the original DOS release, like any music whatsoever, the ability to look up and down, and grabbing onto ledges while jumping. Disregarding the sparseness of features, the gameplay itself is similar enough to Goodbye Galaxy that it doesn’t completely suck. I had a lot of fun with this as a kid, and I still find it to be a unique challenge, with its non-linear progression and the challenges of using flower power due to the arc you throw the seeds at.

So while the gameplay itself is as meh" as ever

recommended: because games like this don’t deserve to be forgotten. Even without my own nostalgia for this title

reviewText: A good port of a solid, if short, classic 2D platformer. I really appreciate that the developer here has actually ported this to modern operating systems rather than just dropping it in Dosbox, and it has the pleasant side effect of their being added achievements which are a nice bonus. Proper controller support and trading cards too! The game crashed when I alt-tabbed out of it, but otherwise seems to be well made and faithful to the original. The game itself has aged decently, though the lack of any music leaves it a bit lacking in the sound department. It's not the best Commander Keen game, but it's definitely not the worst either. I'd say this one is definitely worth picking up, and I hope to see more from this developer in the future. There's a lot of games I'd like to see get this treatment.

reviewText: Keen Dreams is a colorful, fun and addicting classic platformer. And like every good classic, it's surprisingly challenging, but also satisfying once you start getting a hang of it. The Steam version comes with trading cards and achievements. The achievements are a good addition and increase the game's replay value, but note that you cannot get them if you abuse the game's save function: The game is better for it, but unfortunately the player is initially unaware of this and is left wondering why the achievements fail to pop up.

reviewText:
Keen Dreams has always been a good, decent, serviceable game, even though arguably the weakest entry in the Keen series, being basically a stripped-down version of Goodbye, Galaxy!, being a somewhat short stand-alone episode, and especially for lacking music.

The game was originally released as shareware, and there was almost no difference between it and the registered version -- it just didn’t nag you to register upon starting up the game.  Today the shareware version can still be legally obtained for free from various DOS archive sites.  So if you liked the shareware version, you'll like this too, as it's the same game.

It does bear mentioning that the same money will get you both the Invasion and Goodbye packs in the Commander Keen series.  If you're a die-hard Keen fan, it's probably worth it.

I originally left a bad review on this game, but that's unfair, and I ultimately do like the game.  I do stand by my opinion that it pales in comparison to the other Keen titles and it doesn't offer much that the original shareware version always has.  But there's potential here.  The developer did take the time and effort to integrate Steam achievements into the game, and also takes the time to communicate with fans.  That goes a long way.

reviewText:
Lets start by saying this is a very fun and very challenging game that apeals to the old school gammers who first played this in the 90s, aswell as the new baby gammers who dont even know who keen is.

To help you guys or gals who are thinking about buying this game.
You need to know i played this game back in the 90s not when it 1st came out coz i wasnt old enougth to play a pc but never the less i played it in the mid 90s :) .

STORY:
you are billy blaze a 8 year old boy genius (note not them so called apple type geniuses lmao) who after saving the world comes home and eats ice cream instead of his veggies and now they want there  revenge  so go thropugh your dream land and defeat the evil king boobus  and make him regret ever taking you hostage

CONS:
A bit short but worth the £3.99 you pay for it

now to end on the high

PROS:
great fun challenging level design
great control pattern despite i sometimes pressed the windows key and it would exit the game at a stupid point and died :(
great controller support played it with both keybord and xbox 360 controller.
Steam controller runs native to it from go
fun challenging levels
lots of replayability with achivements and high score with diffrent difficultys aswell as secrets hidden through out the levels  including a secret level  you have to cheat to get to but is actualy not a prpoper level more like a test level i think
windowed mode, wide screen support, old school and new school graphics.
my daughter loves playing it. so its child freindly :)

What it could do better on
Workshop so its got more replayability
and not to sure but is there back ground music missing from the levels dont quote me on it as my memorie might be playing tricks on me

so a massive 100/10 to hard disk publishing for bringing this lost gem to us.

and yes i would recomend this game to any one who likes platforming games or someone who wants a fun game they can easily pick up but hard to put down :)

reviewText:
Well what a flashback, as a 32 year old gamer, Who has been playing games since early PC's and Atari,  I truly appreciate this as a long lost Commander Keen game and a hat tip to the old VGA style Games, that spawned Duke Nukem, Wolfensein, Doom and other great games. Long Live ID Software & Apogee.

Now lets get into Keen Dreams.
The controls aren't bad, The Jump is a little wide, but once you get the hang of it its not bad.

I like that is gives you choices of where to go next by a map you explore,
I also like that work like state saves, only problem is it doesn't save on its own so you got to always remember to save.

Game is challenging as you can't kill enemies just temp change them into flowers. Love the fact this company added all these Achievements that is super cool, As well as trading cards. The game is easy and challenging especially at the same time, and especially if your greedy like me trying to get everything.

I thouroughly enjoyed plaiyng this and hope more retro games either come forward or newer games are made in the same style.
Excellent game!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Keen Dreams has always been the black sheep of the series. But that doesn't mean it's bad. In fact for a game that was made in only a month, it's actually a really impressive game. If you're a fan of classic dos platformers or Keen games in general, then I would recommend it, even if it doesn't have the pogo stick or raygun that has been a staple part of the series.

The re-release of Keen Dreams does a really good job with staying true to the original shareware release. However, I do think the price is a little too high for a slightly enhanced shareware game. If it was reduced to about 2 or 3 dollars, then I'd say go for it. Also, it would be nice if there were also some additional content in the game to enhance the overall experience and asking price of 5 dollars, such as an original background music score, some images for the game's story and maybe if possible, a second chapter called Keen Meets the Meats exclusive to this re-release.
As for bugs, I haven't really noticed anything during my full playthrough of the game, and the ones I did are mostly on my computer's end rather than the game itself.
But anyway, here's hoping for more Softdisk games like the Rescue Rover duogy and the Catacombs series! And if possible, maybe a re-release of Keen 6 perhaps?

Hey, a man can dream at least!

reviewText: I don't mind games from the old times… on the contrary I kind of love them. It is the source of every game after all. I would recommend this game unless it would be soooo hard, that even completing one level is like trying to win a lottery. If you fail at one point you need to start the whole level again, and you can easily lose all of your lives before you finish the half of the game. If you love some" challenge then feel free to play it. But it's just too hard for me that I can't seem to enjoy it."

reviewText:
If you're looking for a review you've come to the wrong place, if you're here to cook a pie then read on !
Napoleon from the final puff pastry
You will need:
Ready flaky pastry - 1.5 kg five eggs Flour - 150 g> Sugar - 400 grams Milk - 1200 ml Vanilla sugar - 1 n. Cognac - 1 tbsp. l. Shelled walnuts - glass sequence of preparation: dough defrost naturally at room temperature (defrost time indicated on the package). Cook the custard: grind the egg yolks with a mixer or a whisk to a conventional incandescent and vanilla sugar, flour and brandy to enter the mix. The mixture pour a trickle of milk, stir and cook, stirring constantly. Divide the dough into the desired number of pieces that will later Korzh. Roll out each piece on a board sprinkled with flour. Bake in the oven for about 10 minutes until golden color on a dry baking temperature of 200 degrees. Fluff the cooled cream cakes. If desired, each layer sprinkled with chopped nuts. On top of the cake lightly press smeared with cream and sprinkle all sides crumbs. Add layer cake in a cool place overnight.
